headline: Insights offered on endorsement power of Trump, other leaders
author: Trevor Hubert
sentences:
“It suggests that maybe you don’t have so much political juice that people thought that you had, and that’s been coming up a lot in looking at Trump’s endorsements across the country.”
Mr. Trump is expected to hold a rally on Saturday at the Delaware County Fairgrounds ahead of the May 3 primary, where Mr. Vance is also expected to make an appearance with other Trump-endorsed candidates from around the state.

“We had all the momentum before, and now we really have the momentum.”
At the event, Mr. Vance and Mr. Trump’s eldest son touched on the importance of putting “America First” candidates in Congress to ensure that Mr. Trump has a successful run for president in 2024, should he choose to run.

Nobody seems to have a clear, dominant lead in this primary.”
Ultimately, it was Mr. Vance, who has been attacked by his opponents for his public criticisms of Mr. Trump before he won the 2016 election, who was called on to carry the former president’s torch in Ohio.

After more than a year of campaigning for some of the candidates, the race for the U.S. Senate in Ohio may have finally reached its peak last week, when former President Donald Trump made a much anticipated endorsement of author and venture capitalist J.D.

When breaking down the outside spending for the race, Mr. Vance has had the most outside spending in his favor, all coming from the Protect Ohio Values PAC, bankrolled by venture capitalist and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel.

Mr. Nelson said that the Trump endorsement can still help Mr. Vance in two ways, mainly quelling the worries of Trump voters on his past record, and bringing more attention to his campaign right before the primary.

“We’re in a tight primary on May 3, we’re going to win this race, especially with the president’s endorsement,” Mr. Vance said at a campaign event in the Cleveland area with Donald Trump Jr. earlier this week.
Sam Nelson, a professor in the political science department at the University of Toledo, said that the former president’s endorsement could still be the ultimate trump card at this stage in the race.
The endorsement question was also included in the poll, and 54.9 percent of respondents were either “more likely” or “much more likely” to support a candidate endorsed by the former president.
The group has spent more than $9.5 million in support of the Vance campaign, according to the data reported by OpenSecrets.org, a non-profit that tracks political spending across the country.

State Sen. Matt Dolan (R., Chagrin Falls), has been endorsed by Betty Montgomery, Ohio’s first female attorney general, along with at least three of his General Assembly colleagues.
Mr. Vance and Ms. Timken have both had about $2 million spent in their opposition, but Mr. Gibbons leads the way with nearly $5 million spent in his opposition by outside groups.

It could be a political risk for Mr. Trump to get involved with any primary race, especially if his candidates lose, Mr. Nelson explained.
Or do we get a Republican Senate that is again, saying nice things about him on TV, and stabbing him in the back in the backrooms?
Former Ohio GOP chairman Jane Timken has promoted her record of helping Mr. Trump win the state in the 2020 presidential election.
Former Ohio Treasurer Josh Mandel adopted “pro-God, pro-gun, and pro-Trump” as a common slogan in his campaign advertising.
When weighing the importance of endorsements, it can be difficult to tell which ones move the needle for voters.
Investment banker Mike Gibbons touted himself as a “pro-Trump businessman” in his ads.
“If you endorse people who lose, it takes something away from you yourself,” he said.
Recent polling would suggest that there could be some truth behind that claim.
Many of the candidates have received endorsements from high profile figures.
